Award.AwardTitle: Scalable Manufacturing of Novel Hydrogen Storage Materials with Control at Nanometer Length Scales

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the development of numerical tools and nanomanufacturing processes for characterizing the structure-process-performance relationships of nanosphere coatings on silicon thin films. These coatings have the potential to not only enhance solar efficiencies without introducing additional surface recombination, but also reduce manufacturing processes and costs. The developed numerical tools will determine optimal structures for enhanced efficiencies while considering both ordered and disordered structures. Detailed simulations will be performed on optimal structures to determine the role of scattering and whispering gallery modes as well as to determine the angular performance of coated solar cells and evaluate transport characteristics. Scalable, inexpensive spin coating methods will be used to understand how nanosphere coatings may be assembled onto silicon thin film photovoltaics. Manufactured samples will be characterized structurally, optically, and electronically to validate simulations.

The results of this research will lead to improvements in the design of next-generation solar cells. This could also have a profound impact on other nanophotonic applications that make use of whispering gallery modes such as optical filters and biosensors. A broad impact is envisioned in the areas of solar cells, topology optimization, and nanomanufacturing. This project will also educate and outreach to next-generation engineers through open source software development, the introduction of various education modules, and involvement with the Pitt Office of Diversity's INVESTING NOW summer program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this project is to investigate and develop novel processing methods that can manufacture a large quantity of novel hydrogen storage materials (LiBH4 + MgH2) with control at atomic or low-nanometer length scales. The LiBH4 + MgH2 system has attracted worldwide attention in the last several years because of its potential to store and release hydrogen at relatively low temperatures with a theoretical capacity of 11.6 wt.% H2. Thermodynamically, hydrogen release of the 2LiBH4 + MgH2 mixture at temperature below 200 oC would be possible. However, the 2LiBH4 + MgH2 system has significant kinetic barriers. As a result, significant hydrogen release will not occur until temperature is higher than 300 oC. In this project, we have focused on investigation of a transformative manufacturing method, termed as Ball Milling with Aerosol Spraying (BMAS), to obtain nanoscale LiBH4+MgH2 mixtures, thereby overcoming kinetic barriers and releasing H2 below 200 oC.

Intellectual Merit: We have conceived, designed and established the BMAS process (Figure 1) and used this novel manufacturing method to synthesize nanoscale LiBH4 + MgH2 mixtures. In this process, aerosol droplets of LiBH4 solution are sprayed into the air-tight canister of an attritor, while ball milling of MgH2 powder is taking place. Aerosol liquid droplets will become solid nanoparticles when the droplets impinge on the surface of MgH2 particles and balls where the local temperature can be high (~200 oC) due to the high speed collision of balls. As a result, LiBH4 nanoparticles will coat on the surface of MgH2 particles and be occluded into MgH2 nanoparticles later as ball milling continues because of repeated fracture and cold-welding of MgH2 particles during ball milling. We have shown that nanoscale LiBH4 and MgH2 can react to form MgB2 and LiH with release of H2 if ball milling is performed without water cooling. This is the first time that nanoscale LiBH4 and MgH2 are proven to react near room temperature to release hydrogen gas – a goal long pursued by many investigators but not able to accomplish it. The hydrogen release from the LiBH4+MgH2 mixture near the ambient temperature becomes possible because nanoparticles have low kinetic barriers. In fact, a new reaction pathway, as predicted by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, has been taken by the BMAS-processed nanoscale LiBH4+MgH2 mixture. In contrast, micrometer-sized LiBH4+MgH2 mixtures cannot take this reaction pathway because of their significant kinetic barriers. We have also discovered that by ball milling MgH2 alone first and then infiltrating nanoscale LiHB4 into the ball milled MgH2 powder can result in significant release of H2 from MgH2 at 150 oC (Figure 2). Such an important result has never been achieved before by any other means unless the tactics leading to irreversible reactions is used. The significant release of H2 from MgH2 at 150 oC becomes possible because of the new reaction pathway enabled by nanoscale LiBH4.

Broader Impacts: The novel discoveries and advancements made in this project provide new directions to make the LiBH4 + MgH2 mixture as a viable system for reversible hydrogen storage applications near 150 oC in the near future. The principle established in this project has also opened up a new direction for investigating and improving the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation properties of many other systems containing multiple hydride components that have favorable thermodynamic properties for reversible hydrogen storage, but with limited kinetics. Examples of such systems include CaH2 + LiBH4, Mg(BH4)2 + LiBH4, Ca(BH4)2 + LiBH4, and Mg(BH4)2 + LiBH4 + MgH2. However, none of these systems exhibits adequate kinetics for hydrogen release below 300 oC. Nanoengineering as demonstrated in this project offers a promising approach to address this challenging issue.

This project has provided research training to several graduate students at Illinois Institute of Technology in the areas of hydrogen storage materials, nanopowder synthesis and processing, microstructural characterization, evaluation of hydrogen storage properties, and design of materials processing equipment. In addition, we have actively engaged undergraduate students in research activities and reached out beyond college students by working with ASM International Chicago Chapter for the last three years to provide introductions and lab tours to middle/high school teachers during the ASM International Summer Teacher Camps in Chicago. These middle/high school teachers have become our ambassadors to stimulate the interest of middle and high school students in pursuing careers involving science, engineering and technology. This summer (2016) we also worked with the Chicago Zoological Society to carry out lab tours and demonstrations to about 300 diverse middle and high school students from across the Chicago metro area as part of "Summer 2016 Teen Conservation Leadership Conference". This three-day conference has featured presentations on a variety of topics from industry experts, college professors and students as well as fellow teen participants of the Chicago Zoological Society's King Conservation Science program.
